content:
If the folder has not been compacted, the messages are still there. This article may help: 

https://kb.mozillazine.org/Undelete_a_message
creator: davidsk

content:
This did not solve the problem. However, I found another solution that worked here:

https://smallbusiness.chron.com/recover-deleted-trash-thunderbird-51463.html

The only change I had to make - because I was trying to recover an mbox that contained 100s of emails - was to use search and replace in Notepad to find and replace every instance of X-Mozilla-Status: 000X, where X is a non-zero digit, with X-Mozilla-Status: 0000.

Using these steps, I was able to recover an entire year's worth of messages that I had inadvertently deleted. Hope this helps someone else.
creator: jimheard1

content: THANKS for that feedback. I will definitely keep this info to share with others. I'm glad you resolved your issue. :)

content:
Try this:

Open the TB profile:

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting information

- under the Application Basics section next to Profile Folder, click 'Open folder'

- close TB > rename the handlers.json file in your profile folder

- restart TB > go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information > click the 'Clear startup cache' button

After restarting, when you try to open one of those attachments, you should be presented with a screen where you can choose which app to use.


If that didn't work, try this:

Open the config editor:

- TB menu > Settings > General > scroll all the way down > click the 'Config editor' button

Search for and set these to true:

- network.protocol-handler.warn-external.http

- network.protocol-handler.warn-external.https

Then try to open one of those attachments. If it works, set the two options back to false.
creator: siffemoz

content:
Glennallen, I would recommend for you to contact the company that is providing you with e-mail service, as they would be able to tell you for sure which e-mail settings to use. It appears that your e-mail address ending in dccnet.com is most likely being managed by Delta Cable Communication (EastLink). I found that EastLink publishes the following instructions regarding e-mail settings:

https://help.eastlink.ca/internet-wifi/configuring-your-eastlink-email-address/

It appears that you should be using port 993.

If you are not able to resolve the problem on your own, you might want to try calling EastLink on the phone using their contact information which they provide at this page:

https://help.eastlink.ca/

By the way, after you do get it working, you might want to change the "check for new messages every x minutes" setting. You currently have this set at every 1 minutes, which does create a bit of extra workload for the mail server. Personally, just to be kind to the mail server, I set this to 10 minutes, and whenever I am in a hurry to receive an e-mail that I am expecting, then I will use the "File" menu's "Get New Message" function to manually initiate a mail check.

I hope this helps!
creator: antifascist

content:
yeah,

Eastlink give the server settings to use as https://help.eastlink.ca/internet-wifi/configuring-your-eastlink-email-address/

Incoming mail server settings Account Type: POP or IMAP Server: mail.eastlink.ca Port: 993 Security: SSL/TLS Username: Full email address Password: Your email password

So while Port 995 is the default you don't use it with them.

Now you say you do not get any error message. Really I think that is just about impossible. Is there nothing in the windows notifications, the error console (ctl+Shift+J) or the Thunderbird activity manager

content:
If you're getting unwanted updates, it could be due to a software updater module that's part of some security apps like Norton or Avast.

There have been some recent updates that unfortunately rename server-defined folder names to TB-specific names, e.g. Junk/Bulk folders are now Spam and Sent Mail becomes Sent.

content:
1. What app are you using on your phone? 2. Is your email address one of the legacy roadrunner ones? perhaps one that uses brighthouse servers

Are you using the spectrum service to connect to the internet? I have seen several issues of late where the problem is spectrum refuse to send mail unless you connect using an IP address they consider they issued. SO a VPN will automatically fail. Non spectrum hotspots will fail as will wifi in hotels and motels unless you luck out by being in a business that shares a provider with you. One chap was in Houston on business, suddenly he could not send mail.

Given the skills I am seeing of late from Spectum it is entirely possible they have blocked a larger swathe of their own users from sending mail via their own SMTP server because they have a skills issue. They do not apply the sending restriction to their webmail, only to sending via their SMTP server.

Goto this link https://whatismyipaddress.com/

3. Is your ISP given as Spectrum? 4. What is the IPV4 address given at that website?

content: Thunderbird 115 is a rather old version, which I believe is causing the issue here as Google would have made some changes on their end since then. Upgrading Thunderbird to the latest version should resolve your issue. Since you are using an old version of Ubuntu as well, you may have to download the ESR release of Thunderbird, which should be newer than the version you are on now and it should still work on your version of Ubuntu as well. You can download it here and ensure the "Release Channel" drop down option is set to "Thunderbird Extended Support Release".

content:
I suppose you're still running TB 140.7.1esr now?

Gmail uses OAuth authentication. That means you'll have to allow cookies in Thunderbird for the authentication to succeed.

Are you using a VPN? If so, turn it off for the authentication.

Are you running a local web server, or any other service which may occupy TCP port 80 on your computer? If so, turn it off for the authentication.
creator: christ1

content:
I located the problem

The application /snap/upnp-server was listening on port 80 locallyvia the lighthttpd damon. Once I terminated that application Thunderbird was able to complete authentication.

Thanks for you assistance.

content:
I'm not clear what your intention is. Are you trying to do a virgin install, as if Thunderbird was never on this computer? And there is nothing from a previous installation that you want to preserve, like old email and accounts? If so, look in the location where the user profiles are stored, which is, by default,

C:\Users\<your user name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird

Rename the Thunderbird folder to something like "Thunderbird.OLD" and try installing Thunderbird again. When you first run it after installing, it should create a fresh new profile for you and prompt you to create new accounts. Once everything is working the way you want, you can go back and delete the "Thunderbird.OLD" folder.

If this isn't what you're trying to do, please clarify and provide more details.
creator: rednoise

content: If you click the .thunderbird folder, you will likely see another profile named 'profile.' and in that folder will be real profiles. The active profile was identified in the file, profiles.ini. You can verify that by then opening that profile where you should see your accounts and recent dates for update. That is the profile folder to which I was referring in my earlier response. By just replacing the profile folder, you excuse yourself from figuring out how thunderbird is ordering things.
creator: davidsk

content:
The folder index and message list may have somehow gotten out of sync or the index is damaged. If so, easy fix:

- The first thing to try is to compact the folder (right-click on the folder name and choose "Compact".

- If that doesn't fix the problem, go on to the next possible fix, which is to Repair the folder. This is safe, but you might find that some messages you deleted earlier now re-appear. Right-click on the folder name, Properties, General Information, and click the "Repair Folder" button.
creator: rednoise

content: have you checked you apples notification area for connection errors or refusals of logins? What about Thunderbird activity monitor and error console?

content:
Thank you for your help. View folders is "unified folders" with a unified inbox, and each account (except the gmail account) has a separate inbox as a sub folder. The missing gmail inbox is a puzzle. I have 5 other email accounts.

Earlier, the Activity Mgr showed the download of my test message I senr to the gmail account, but I couldn't find the message. Now, I cannot find that in the Activity Mgr.

I'm on an M4 macbook pro with 24 gigs of memory. I'm wonder if I should just wipe the gmail account and start over if that would solve the problem.

Thank you, again.
creator: dpauker

content:
dpauker said
View folders is "unified folders" with a unified inbox, and each account (except the gmail account) has a separate inbox as a sub folder.

Unified Folders is important info and probably it will be easy to get your Gmail inbox back in unified folders view. • R-click on the unified Inbox folder at the top and select "Properties" in the context menu; this will open a new window called "Edit Saved Search Properties for Inbox" (see image) • click on the button "Choose" to open another window called "Select Folder(s)" which displays a list of all accounts with all folders.. • search for your missing Gmail Inbox, set a check mark, click OK and then on the Update button Now you should see your Gmail Inbox displayed in the Unified Folder view
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thank you! That did it.
creator: dpauker

content: Glad to help you. Unfortunately you chose your own reply from today as helpful message instead of my message which allowed you to solve your problem.
